title: Firefighter attends fatal crash to discover victim is his own niece
text:
Yorkshire firefighter Nathan Williams found his 18-year-old niece Jordan dead at the scene (Picture: Triangle News)

A firefighter called out to a car crash was left heartbroken after realising it was his niece who had died in the accident.

Nathan Williams, 32, did not initially recognise the teenage victim, killed in the crash in South Yorkshire on Saturday.

But moments later, he realised it was his niece Jordan Williams, who leaves behind a young son.

The 18-year-old was a passenger in a Renault Clio which span out of control and flipped onto its roof after hitting a wall in Monk Bretton, near Barnsley.

Her sister Katie, 16, was travelling in a car behind and watched Jordan’s life slip away.

Jordan’s 19-month-old son Riley was sleeping at his great-grandparents’ home at the time and he has stayed in their care.

South Yorkshire Police said the Renault’s driver, an 18-year-old male, was arrested at the scene but later released.

Jordan with her 19-month-old son Riley (Picture: Triangle News)

Jordan’s grandmother, Lesley Hallworth, 57, said Nathan was in ‘major shock’ but managed to ring his brother Scott, who rushed to the scene with the family.

She said: ‘We got the call and it just floored us. We had Riley with us and it is very very hard to deal with.

‘He has no idea what has happened, thank God. He is an angel and an absolute dream to look after.’

‘That’s credit to Jordan who was a brilliant mum.’

Nathan, a former Royal Marine who has been a fireman for around 12 years, assured his family that Jordan would not have felt pain before her death.

The crash happened shortly after 5am on October 19.

Jordan’s mum, Kat, 39, said: ‘Jordan was stunning and she loved her little boy. She was very, very open and had no filter.’

Nathan Williams, 32, was in shock after the discovery (Picture: Triangle News)

Scott, Jordan’s step-father, also 39, was close to Jordan and described her as ‘an absolute nutter’.

‘She really did love life and she really lived it,’ he added.

Lesley has set up a fundraising page for Riley, who she is looking after with husband Ian, and said she could not thank people enough for the ‘absolutely overwhelming’ response so far.

Jordan also leaves behind three siblings, Katie, 16, Liam, 11 and Maddison, five.

South Yorkshire Police have asked for witnesses to come forward.

A spokesperson said: ‘The Clio was believed to have been travelling behind a white Citroen C1.’

‘Officers would like to speak to anyone who witnessed the collision, who may have seen the driving manner of either vehicle prior to the collision, or who may have any information that can help with our enquiries.’

Jordan’s family are being supported by specially trained officers, he added.
